title: 108_s2819
content: The Act titled "Higher Education Preparation Program Act of 2004" defines key terms such as Secretary, secondary school, institution of higher education, and State educational agency. It also outlines the curriculum for the Higher Education Preparation Program. The Higher Education Preparation Program Act of 2004 authorizes the Secretary to award grants to nonprofit organizations to develop a curriculum-based program for students in grades 8, 9, and 10. The program aims to educate students about higher education opportunities, help them prepare for college applications, and provide one hour of instruction per week. Nonprofit organizations must submit an application to the Secretary to be considered for a grant. The Secretary may require time and information for grant applications. Grants are awarded based on the nonprofit organization's ability to develop the higher education preparation program curriculum. SEC. 4. HIGHER EDUCATION PREPARATION PROGRAM DEMONSTRATION PROJECT. The Secretary will establish a demonstration project to award grants to State educational agencies for higher education preparation programs for students in grades 8, 9, and 10. Up to 5 State educational agencies will receive grants for a 5-year period. Each agency must apply for a grant. Each State educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary to receive a grant for implementing a higher education preparation program in middle and secondary schools. The grant funds can be used for curriculum development and enrichment activities like guest speakers and videos. The Secretary considers the number of middle schools when awarding grants. The Secretary considers the number of middle and secondary schools with low rates of student application and admission to higher education when awarding grants. Priority is given to students in these schools for participation in the higher education preparation program. State educational agencies must ensure that participating schools submit annual progress reports. The demonstration project must submit annual progress reports to the State educational agency and the Secretary. The Secretary must provide Congress with annual progress reports on the demonstration project and a final report with recommendations after its conclusion. $10,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2005 to 2010 to carry out the Act.
